instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
No liquid damage.
PP3V42 is 0.6V
PPBUS is 1.2V
ACOK is 1.1V

Change <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> as usual culprit?
Any other suggestion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> needs to be 3.42v first. 16v on <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>? <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> 47 ohms? Resistance to ground on pin 2 of L6995?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> is 14V. <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is 33 oms. Resistance to ground on L6995 is around 17k omhs.
I also just noticed that the MCP was messed with. (Possibly reflowed/reballed/changed who knows)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Inject 3V42 and see if the green light comes on and the machine works. No use in fixing 3V42 and then discovering the MCP is also fucked.
